image.altText: Two men, one wearing a grey suit and a hat, the other a blue suit, flank a shorter blonde woman.

items.synopsis: After standing by his side in May, Liberal defector John Tucker now says Premier Jeremy Rockliff should be toppled by his deputy Michael Ferguson to "stop the mistakes" — and bring about an end to Tasmania's political instability.

title.children: Deputy urged to roll Rockliff, as key independent calls for Tasmanian election

image.altText: Smoke fills the air over mountainous bushland.

items.synopsis: A weather front is bringing rain relief for emergency services tackling a bushfire on Flinders Island that earlier forced evacuations — with residents urged to continue monitoring the "changeable" conditions.

title.children: Rain relief for crews fighting Flinders Island bushfire

image.altText: flames light up night sky behind houses

items.synopsis: Bushfire emergencies are unfolding in multiple states, with hundreds of firefighters battling blazes in Victoria while an emergency warning for Flinders Island in Tasmania's north-east has been downgraded. Follow live.

title.children: Fires in Victoria, NSW reach emergency level as Tasmanian fire downgraded

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Bridget Murphy A large contingent of fire trucks have arrived in Kearsley, near Cessnock. Crews from Hornsby in Sydney, and other towns from the Hunter Valley region are responding to the fast moving fire. It has burned more than 100 hectares and is out of control. A fire nearby is burning at an emergency level, with residents in nearby Elrington and Abernathy told it's too late to leave, and to shelter in place.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Crews working to control 100 hectare fire in Kearsley, NSW

children.content: Reporting by Bridget Murphy
A large contingent of fire trucks have arrived in
Kearsley,
near Cessnock.
(ABC News: Bridget Murphy)
Crews from Hornsby in Sydney, and other towns from the
Hunter Valley region
are responding to the fast moving fire.
(ABC News: Bridget Murphy)
It has burned more than
100 hectares
and is out of control.
A fire nearby is burning at an emergency level, with residents in nearby
Elrington
and
Abernathy
told it's too late to leave, and to shelter in place.
(ABC News: Bridget Murphy)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While fire conditions are expected to ease, there are now severe weather warnings for most of the eastern part of Victoria for heavy rainfall that could lead to flash flooding. The Bureau of Meteorology's Christie Johnson says 30 to 60mm of rain is expected to drench the area, and possibly even 70 to 80mm in parts of the ranges. She says a low pressure system will start to develop tomorrow which will bring more wet weather. "There is quite a lot of rainfall expected to fall over 6 to 12 hours,"Johnson says. "So even if it's not that heavy rainfall where you get a huge amount in a short time, it could still be enough to overwhelm gutters and give some flash flooding." Conditions are expected to be much clearer on Friday and into the weekend.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Flash flooding risk in Victoria's east today and tomorrow

children.content: While fire conditions are expected to ease, there are now
severe weather warnings
for most of the eastern part of Victoria for heavy rainfall that could lead to
flash flooding

props.alt: Meteorologist Christie Johnson addressing the media with a serious look on her face.

children.content: Meteorologist Christie Johnson says there are severe weather warnings for flash flooding and damaging winds.
(ABC News)
The Bureau of Meteorology's
Christie Johnson
says 30 to 60mm of rain is expected to drench the area, and possibly even 70 to 80mm in parts of the ranges.
She says a low pressure system will start to develop tomorrow which will bring more wet weather.
"There is quite a lot of rainfall expected to fall over 6 to 12 hours,"Johnson says.
"So even if it's not that heavy rainfall where you get a huge amount in a short time, it could still be enough to overwhelm gutters and give some flash flooding."
Conditions are expected to be much clearer on Friday and into the weekend.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Watch and Act warning has now been issued for Cobbannah, Culloden, and Moornapa communities in Victoria. "It is strongly recommended that you prepare to evacuate," Victoria emergency services say. The bushfire at Duffy Rd, Briagolong, is not yet under control and is currently travelling in a south-easterly direction. However, it is expected to change direction to the north-east after the wind changes this afternoon. "While the change in weather has slowed the fire spread, there is still active danger in the landscape," Victoria emergency services say.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victoria residents strongly advised to 'prepare to evacuate'

However, it is expected to change direction to the north-east after the wind changes this afternoon.
"While the change in weather has slowed the fire spread, there is still active danger in the landscape," Victoria emergency services say.

image.altText: A middle-aged woman in a purple outfit and weading glasses sits on a plush chair with her hands in her lap.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has left the cash rate unchanged at 4.1 per cent for the fourth month in a row at Michele Bullock's first meeting as governor, but warns another rate hike may be needed as uncertainty grows around oil prices.

title.children: RBA keeps rates steady at 4.1 per cent but warns future increases may be likely to tame inflation

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

items.synopsis: The local share market falls sharply as investors bet on interest rates staying higher for longer, while the value of the Australian dollar, gold and oil suffer heavy losses. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX wipes out all its gains of 2023, RBA keeps rates on hold but doesn't rule out future increase

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Unfortunately, we can't provide advice on what the best course of action is to take with your mortgage — we aren't licensed to do so (it's also why we have that little disclaimer at the top of the blog). That said, there are thousands of home owners who are coming off their fixed rate and are bracing for the impact of these higher rates. A few months ago our colleague Stephanie Chalmers pulled together this handy guide if you're already struggling with mortgage repayments. But if you're trying to get ahead of the curve, we've also got you covered. Emily Stewart asked the experts this very question last year, and pulled together this quick guide to help you prepare — and who to ask for advice. I've linked it below for you to have a read of (or you can bookmark it for another day).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: My fixed rate mortgage is expiring soon, what's the best way forward?

featuredLink.title: 'Start preparing for the mortgage cliff while you can', experts warn fixed rate borrowers

children.content: Unfortunately, we can't provide advice on what the best course of action is to take with your mortgage — we aren't licensed to do so (it's also why we have that little disclaimer at the top of the blog).
That said, there are thousands of home owners who are coming off their fixed rate and are bracing for the impact of these higher rates.

Stephanie Chalmers
pulled together
this handy guide if you're already struggling with mortgage repayments

I've linked it below for you to have a read of (or you can bookmark it for another day).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It has been suggested that the better way to take spending money out of the economy would be to raise the superannuation contribution percentage rather than interest rates. This way you would get the money back plus interest at retirement rather than it going to banks in interest! - Lindsay. That's true! I wrote a piece along those lines in February (which is being put into a commerce textbook soon). Once you start thinking about alternative ways of managing inflation (that depend on the type of inflation you want to fix), the current way of doing things seems really unsophisticated. Philip Lowe said so himself, in recent weeks. This is what he said in September (last month!): "My view has long been that if we were designing optimal policy arrangements from scratch, monetary and fiscal policy would both have a role in managing the economic cycle and inflation, and there would be close coordination. "In principle, fiscal policy could provide a stronger helping hand, although this would require some rethinking of the existing policy architecture. "In particular, it would require making some fiscal instruments more nimble, strengthening the (semi) automatic stabilisers and giving an independent body limited control over some fiscal instruments. "I've noticed that people like Olivier Blanchard, who taught me when I was at MIT and then was chief economist at the IMF, he's recently been talking about fiscal policy being used in this way through the creation of some semi-automatic stabilisers, [where] some of the fiscal parameters get adjusted almost mechanically, or that you give an independent body, not the Reserve Bank, but some other independent body, the authority to adjust fiscal instruments within a certain range. "So that's quite a different institutional set-up from the one we have now. "It may not be better than what we have now, but given the limitations of monetary policy ... you know, what we're doing affects people very unevenly, I think we should aspire to kind of something better. "Exploring some of these ideas might be the right way, [or] they may not be," he said. In that imagined scenario of his, I don't see why there couldn't be an opportunity to start manipulating the superannuation guarantee to control certain types of inflation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Different ways of managing inflation?

featuredLink.title: Is there a better way to kill inflation than raising interest rates?

children.content: It has been suggested that the better way to take spending money out of the economy would be to raise the superannuation contribution percentage rather than interest rates. This way you would get the money back plus interest at retirement rather than it going to banks in interest!
- Lindsay
That's true!
I wrote a piece along those lines in February (which is being put into a commerce textbook soon).
Once you start thinking about alternative ways of managing inflation (that depend on the type of inflation you want to fix), the current way of doing things seems really unsophisticated.
Philip Lowe said so himself, in recent weeks.
This is what he said in September (last month!):
"My view
has long been that
if we were designing optimal policy arrangements from scratch, monetary and fiscal policy would both have a role in managing the economic cycle and inflation
, and there would be close coordination.
"In principle,
fiscal policy could provide a stronger helping hand, although this would require some rethinking of the existing policy architecture
"In particular,
it would require making some fiscal instruments more nimble
, strengthening the (semi) automatic stabilisers and giving an independent body limited control over some fiscal instruments.

"I've noticed that people like Olivier Blanchard, who taught me when I was at MIT and then was chief economist at the IMF, he's recently been talking about fiscal policy being used in this way through the creation of some semi-automatic stabilisers, [where] some of the fiscal parameters get adjusted almost mechanically, or that
you give an independent body, not the Reserve Bank, but some other independent body, the authority to adjust fiscal instruments within a certain range
"So that's quite a different institutional set-up from the one we have now.
"It may not be better than what we have now, but given the limitations of monetary policy ... you know,
what we're doing affects people very unevenly
, I think we should aspire to kind of something better.
"Exploring some of these ideas might be the right way, [or] they may not be," he said.
In that imagined scenario of his, I don't see why there couldn't be an opportunity to start manipulating the superannuation guarantee to control certain types of inflation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The RBA's decision to keep rates on hold for another month has not helped the value of Australia's dollar. It's fallen again in the last hour and a half, and is now trading around 63.17 US cents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia dollar falls again

children.content: The RBA's decision to keep rates on hold for another month has not helped the value of Australia's dollar.
It's fallen again in the last hour and a half, and is now trading around 63.17 US cents.

image.altText: Anika Wells speaks in parliament.

items.synopsis: The federal Labor minister was diagnosed with an autoimmune disease during her first pregnancy and says, like others with invisible diseases, she does not want people drawing their own conclusions about her illness.

title.children: Why Anika Wells doesn't publicly name her chronic illness

image.altText: Smoke burning over homes

items.synopsis: An emergency warning is issued for two out-of-control bushfires in New South Wales which are threatening homes and properties.

title.children: Residents told it's too late to leave as two out-of-control bushfires are upgraded to emergency

image.altText: A boat moored by a small jetty with an orange fire burning in the background over the water.

items.synopsis: Spot fires are flaring up 11 kilometres ahead of an East Gippsland fire front that has residents in an isolated coastal town preparing to evacuate by boat.

title.children: Victorian residents prepare for boat evacuations after Gippsland town cut off by bushfires

image.altText: Chris Minns wearing a high-vis vest

items.synopsis: The Minns government has faced calls to allow for pill testing at events in the state following the deaths of two men who attended the Knockout Outdoor music festival in Western Sydney last weekend.

title.children: 'A toxic combination': NSW premier issues drugs warning as man charged over festival death

image.altText: A young woman in a fluoro vest with pink glasses standing between trains.

items.synopsis: Chelsea Taylor thought university was the only option after school. But after three unfinished degrees and $30,000 in student debt, she felt "really, really lost" — until she became a train driver.

title.children: After racking up a big student debt, Chelsea became a train driver. She says career advice is limiting teenagers

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair cries while sitting in a police interview room

items.synopsis: Biannca Edmunds has been sentenced to 26 years' jail after a botched assassination plan she hatched with her husband, targeting her ex-partner, resulted in both mens' deaths.

title.children: Judge says woman showed 'extreme' entitlement by plotting to kill her ex-partner over custody issues

image.altText: Illustration of Australia with night sky and stars in background and yellow circle in middle of Australia.

items.synopsis: On October 14, every Australian will be asked to answer a yes or no question. What you write on the ballot paper will determine whether our constitution is changed for the first time in more than four decades. Here's everything you need to know before you vote.

title.children: Your Voice voting cheat sheet: All your referendum questions, answered

image.altText: Composite image of two photos of a man - a selfie with him smoking a cigar and a mugshot. Around him are passport stamps.

items.synopsis: The work undercover operatives and sources do is a key weapon against organised crime. These men say our law enforcement agencies have abandoned them.

title.children: This Australian is sitting in a foreign prison cell. He's ready to come clean about his life undercover

image.altText: Kacey and Layne stand together smiling on a suburban street.

items.synopsis: Less than half of the federal government's promised urgent care clinics have opened, months after the policy was supposed to be delivered.

title.children: After waiting six hours in an emergency department, Kasey is wondering where her city's Urgent Care Clinic is

image.altText: A girl sits up in bed, hugging her knees to her chest. Her face is blurred by a sheet of tempered glass.

items.synopsis: ABC Investigations has established more than 1,500 people have reported alleged sexual assaults and harassment in mental health wards over the past six years in Australia. It is launching a national crowdsourced investigation into mental health units and is asking people to share their experiences.

title.children: Florence was allegedly raped in her hospital room. She wants her story told to keep others safe

image.altText: Stan Grant in a suit and short

items.synopsis: Michael Steven Davis, 41, allegedly used his Facebook and Twitter profiles to threaten "serious harm" in May.

title.children: Man accused of abusing Stan Grant online has three charges dropped, offers to apologise

image.altText: nsw police at a crime scene where a woman was found inside a home in Bankstown

items.synopsis: Police allege the 31-year-old man stabbed his mother to death, killed her cat and set the family home on fire in Sydney's south west.

title.children: Son allegedly killed mother a day after being granted bail for attacking her, court told

image.altText: Three people stand in the background, between two purple and white YES signs

items.synopsis: The Yes23 campaign has been asked to keep signs for the Yes vote coloured in purple and white away from Australian Electoral Commission signage.

title.children: Yes23 campaign warned over signs which could 'mislead' voters at polling stations

image.altText: Two people sit on a stage smiling, both wearing t-shirts that say Vote No to the Voice of Division

items.synopsis: More than 1,000 vocal No supporters are urged by Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Nyunggai Warren Mundine not to get complacent ahead of the historic referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Price and Mundine issue rallying cry to No crowd in Perth as Voice vote draws closer

image.altText: Donald Trump sits in court and looks straight ahead. The gallery behind him is full of people.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump is fighting a civil lawsuit that could cost him control of his prized properties and his freedom to do business in New York. Here's what happened on day one of the trial.

title.children: Trump doesn't show up to court unless he's forced. Here's why he chose to appear at his fraud trial

image.altText: A drone shot of a new housing estate, with houses stretching as far as the eye can see

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has kept interest rates on hold, but more hikes are expected later this year as 550,000 people come off fixed mortgages. The RBA itself warns that could put more people in financial stress, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: RBA warns 'solid middle-to-upper-income' people are the new borrowers in financial stress

image.altText: A woman, covering her head in a blanket, sits looking upward, surrounded by barbed wire

items.synopsis: Several hundred migrants in southern Mexico wait for buses to the country's north in a new government program meant to help manage the number of people entering the country.

title.children: Mexico sends buses to collect migrants as thousands reach US border

image.altText: A man in a woven headdress stands in a field, looking solemn

items.synopsis: Japan's Ainu people have their own history, languages and culture. But, as the victims of colonialism, assimilation and discrimination, much of that identity has been lost. This is the story of their fight to be recognised.

title.children: For years, Japan tried to keep their existence a secret. But the Ainu people refuse to disappear

image.altText: An illustration shows several hands, arranged in a circle, holding sheets of paper marked with the Chinese flag.

items.synopsis: Australian law firms acting for the Chinese state are simultaneously completing work for the Australian government, raising concerns over sensitive work being done by those firms.

title.children: Beijing-owned businesses using Australian law firms to advise on takeovers of critical projects

image.altText: Anthony Daniels smiles holding up a gold light-up robotic looking head.

items.synopsis: A trove of costumes and props will go under the hammer in a sale of film and television memorabilia worth around $23 million.

title.children: C-3PO's head, Titanic costumes among memorabilia for sale at film auction

image.altText: A seaside suburbia seen from above, with some houses still under construction.

items.synopsis: Researchers at Swinburne University of Technology have developed a tool to calculate the social, economic and environmental benefits of social and affordable housing.

title.children: New calculator tool estimates 40,000 new social and affordable housing will have $4.4 billion benefit

image.altText: Split screen image of a woman and a man on ABC's Q+A.

items.synopsis: As Senator Malarndirri McCarthy reveals the moment she felt most "disempowered", a debate focused on who the Voice will help takes over Q+A.

title.children: 'Disadvantage' locked into the constitution or 'significant moment'? Voice debate heats up on Q+A

image.altText: A woman smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: The survivor of a terrifying shark attack at Beachport in South Australia's south-east initially thought the animal was another swimmer, her husband says — but he has little doubt his wife will return to the water after recovering in hospital and at home.

title.children: Shark that attacked early morning swimmer 'looked like a white pointer', husband says

image.altText: A screenshot of a video game. A large red army is being approached by a small blue one. They're in a walled off area

items.synopsis: Scientists use Age of Empires to simulate ant warfare, with the aim of helping native ant species better fight their invasive counterparts.

title.children: Invasive ants are a huge problem in Australia, but a classic computer game could help solve it

image.altText: a map of eastern australia showing hot temperatures for those parts

items.synopsis: The frequent spells of early spring heat resulted in Australia's third-warmest September on record since 1910, with a national temperature 2.4C above the climatological average.

title.children: The heat won't stay: Temperatures to drop by as much as 20 degrees in 48 hours

image.altText: A smiling baby in a blanket.

items.synopsis: The parents of Alyviah Hayne, who died in 2015, say they'll never recover from their loss. Jake Robert Luscombe will serve at least four years behind bars over the baby's death.

title.children: Family of seven-month-old say they'll 'never heal' as killer is sentenced

image.altText: A pilot stands beside heavily-armed rebels in Papua.

items.synopsis: Rebels were armed with military-grade weapons and arrows when a battle broke out between them and a joint military and police force, with the group saying the deaths of their fighters would not lead to their surrender.

title.children: Members of Papuan rebel group behind kidnapping of New Zealand pilot killed in clashes with security forces

image.altText: A baby is held by an adult as it is given a vaccine injection in its right leg.

items.synopsis: The new three shot vaccine is said to be more than 75 per cent effective, while experts say the jab won't stop malaria but could play a part in reducing deaths and severe illness.

title.children: UN authorises a second malaria vaccine, but experts warn it's not enough to stop the disease spreading

image.altText: Benedict Cumberbatch in red pyjamas sits in a cross legged meditation position in front of a bright background

items.synopsis: Theatrics, decorative wallpaper and the good in people: Wes Anderson brings his whimsy to Roald Dahl's The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar

title.children: In just 39 minutes Wes Anderson brings The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar to life
